msItem.incipit: አብ፡ ወወልድ፡ ወመንፈስ፡ ቅዱስ፡ ኅቡራነ፡ ህላዌ፡ በ፩መንበር። ህላዌ፡ አብ፡ ኢይትሌለይ፡ እምህላዌ፡ ወልድ፡ ወመንፈስ፡ ቅዱስ። ህላዌ፡ ወልድ፡ ኢይትፈለጥ፡ እምህላዌ፡ አብ፡ ወመንፈስ፡ ቅዱስ።
msItem.explicit:
ግዕዘ፡ መንፈስ፡ ቅዱስ፡ ፩ምስለ፡ አብ፡ ወምስለ፡ ወልድ። በዝንቱ፡ ሥላሴ፡ ኅቡር፡ ተማኅፀንኩ፡ ወአማኅፀንኩ፡ ነፍስየ፡ ወሥጋየ፡ ከመ፡ ይምሐረኒ፡ ወይሣሃለኒ፡ በእንተ፡ ቅዱስ፡ ሥላሴሁ፡ ሊተ፡ ገብሩ፡

msItem.incipit: አብ፡ ወወልድ፡ ወመንፈስ፡ ቅዱስ፡ በግፃዌ፡ ሥሉስ፡ በሥላሴ፡ ግጽው፡ ዋህድ፡ አምላክ፡ ፫አዕማደ፡ ብርሃን፡ ፩አምጣኖሙ፡ ወ፩ስኖሙ፡ ፫መባርቅት፡
msItem.explicit:
በዝንቱ፡ ስመ፡ ሥላሴ፡ ተማኅፀንኩ፡ ከመ፡ ይክፍለኒ፡ ሥላሴ፡ ቅዱስ፡ እምተስፋ፡ ቅዱሳን፡ እንተ፡ ይእቲ፡ ደብተራ፡ ጽድቅ፡ ጽዮን፡ ሊተ፡ ገብርከ፡

msItem.incipit: ዓይ፡ ልሳን፡ ወዓይ፡ ከናፍር፡ ዘይክል፡ ነቢበ፡ ዕበየ፡ ክብሩ፡ ለሥላሴ፡ ዓይ፡ ልቡና፡ ወዓይ፡ ሰሚዕ፡ ዘይክል፡ አእምሮ፡ ህላዌሆሙ፡ ለሥላሴ።
msItem.explicit:
ስብሐ፡ ለእግዚአብሔር፡ ሰብእ፡ ወመላእክት፡
ኢየአምርዎ፡ ለምክሩ፡ ወለምሥጢሩ። ለዓለመ፡ ዓለም፡ አሜን። ወአሜን፡ ለይኵን፡ ለይኩን። ዕቀበኒ፡ ወአድኅነኒ፡ እመከራ፡ ሥጋ፡ ወነፍስ፡ ሊተ፡ ለገብርከ፡

msItem.incipit: ሰላም፡ ለፍቅረ፡ መለኮት፡ በትስብእቱ፡ ዘጸመ። እንበይነ፡ ዚአነ፡ አርአያሁ፡ ከመ፡ የሀበነ። ሰላም፡ ለፍቅረ፡ መለኮት፡ ዘይፄዓን፡ ላዕለ፡ ሠረገላ፡ ኪሩቤል፡ በትስብእቱ፡ ተፅዕነ፡ ዲበ፡ ዕዋል።
msItem.explicit: ስብሐት፡ ለሥላሴ፡ አብ፡ ወወልድ፡ ወመንፈስ፡ ቅዱስ፡ ምሉዕ፡ በኵለሄ፡ ለሥላሴ፡ ይደሉ፡ ስባሔ፡ እዉድ፡ በሱራኄ፡ ለዓለመ፡ ዓለም፡ አሜን። ወአሜን፡ ለይኵን፡ ለይኩን።

msItem.incipit: አኃሥሥ፡ ጽድቀ፡ እምኀቤከ፡ ኦቀመረ፡ ጽድቅ። አኃሥሥ፡ ጥበበ፡ እምኀቤከ፡ ኦሙዳየ፡ ጥብብ። ኦሥሉስ፡ ቅዱስ፡ አብ፡ ወወልድ፡ ወመንፈስ፡ ቅዱስ፡
msItem.explicit:
ዛቲ፡ ክርታስ፡ ሲሳይ፡ መንፈሳዊት፡ ለዘቦ፡ ሃይማኖት፡ በደኃሪት፡ ዕለት፡ ት
ባልሕ፡ እሞት፡ አሜን፡ ወአሜን፡ ለይኩን፡ ለይኩን። ወአድኅነኒ፡ ወባልሐኒ፡ ሊተ፡ ለኃጥእ፡ ሊተ፡ ገብርከ፡
ገብረ፡
ማርያም፡ወለጸሐፊሁ፡ መሐሮ፡ ወዕቀቦ፡ ለገብርከ፡ ገብረ፡
ወለወልደ፡ ሚካኤልኒ፡ ዕቀቦ፡ ወአድኅኖ።

msItem.note: The hymnodic portrait poem praises the Trinity and comprises 47 strophes.
msItem.incipit: ሰላም፡ ለህላዌክሙ፡ ዘይመውዕ፡ ህላዌያተ። ለረኪበ፡ ስሙ፡ ኅቡዕ፡ አመ፡ ወጠንኩ፡ ተምኔተ። እምግብርክሙ፡ ሥላሴ፡ ሶበ፡ ረከቡ፡ አስማተ። መለኮተ፡ ለለ፩ዘዚአክሙ፡ ገጻተ። እንበለ፡ ትድምርት፡ እሰሚ፡ ወእሁብ፡ ትድምርተ። ሰላም፡ ለዝክረ፡ ስምክሙ፡ ዘኢትጋባዕ፡ እምተከፍሎ።

decoDesc.summary: Monochrome interlace bands in the "Menelik style" mark the incipit pages of : . Such bands are not present on even though the scribe left a few lines above the page for them to be inserted. Most of these bands are topped by indications for the reading days of the week which are encircled by smaller decorative frames drawn by using a different ink. The fact that such readings are also indicated when the interlace bands are absent strongly suggests that they were not added by the illustrator.

item.desc: The pencil note was probably written by .

Aids for identifying weekday readings are written in the upper margin on the incipit page of each section of in red ink (the scribe used a different nib for the reading references than for the main text): ዘሰኑይ () ዘሠሉስ (), ዘረቡዕ (), ዘሐሙስ (), ዘዓርብ (), ዘቀዳሚት (), ዘዘወትር (, in black), ዘእኁድ ().

Scribal corrections occur occasionally over erasure (e.g. here comprising several lines) or interlineally (e.g. ), also made in a secondary hand (e.g. ). Spaces (after erasure) were filled with an interlaced band on and with several thin lines on . The scribe wrote the last two lines of in small script in order to complete the section on the same folio . Writing exercises were executed on and upside down on . The name is written on (the rest of the entire folio is blank).

A turquoise and gold label of the textile trading company A.H. Huschke & Co with a leaping horse is sewn onto . This India-based company was active in the 19th century until its founder, August Henry Huschke of Swiss-German family background, died in 1866 and his company was sold. A.H. Huschke & Co acquired a high ‘reputation for luxury cottons’ and other ‘quality goods for the fashion market’

A white sticker, with the name of (ቤንት፡ ዩውል፡ የንሰን።) printed on it, and the signatures ‘Ms. Aeth. f. 29’ written in pencil, is respectively glued on and on . Other two stickers with the signature ‘Ms 19’ printed on them are glued on .

binding.decoNote: The book is bound in wooden boards covered with blind-tooled . The lower board is decorated with a textile inlay.

The boards project beyond the edges of the textblock and have a steep internal bevel that stops to the size of the bookblock. A niche possibly for a is carved into the inner side of the upper board (the mirror is lost, but traces of adhesive are still visible). The inner side of the lower board is decorated with a silk (or cotton) inlay coloured gold, blue, and red (see ).

Full reddish-brown leather cover. The turn-ins have been trimmed out and, at the corners, they form butt mitres. Additional leather patches reduce the size of the area between the turn-ins. Blind-tooled ornaments decorate the cover in full, including turn-ins, edges, and spine. The cover sides present a slightly different design consisting of a rectangular frame of motifs between triple straight lines and double straight lines, enclosing a central panel with a star. In the areas above and below the star are triangular-shaped patterns formed by superimposed motifs with double circles at the top. The star is formed by V-form motis and double circles. The lower board presents a 4-pointed star while the upper board an 8-pointed one with the addition of motifs. Triple straight lines run along the edges of the boards. Four-fold straight lines form rectangular panels on the spine and outline the borders of the the turn-ins. Groups of four double circles fill in the empty spaces and are stamped at the intersection of the lines.
The endbands are not extant but their internal tiedowns are visible in the centrefolds of the quires.
Chainstitch sewing on four sewing stations (two pairs). Two Z-plied threads have been used. Their ends are knotted in the centrefold of the last quire.
Two lines of running stitches close to head and tail are visible on the back cover, they are part of the attachment system of the endbands.
Coloured leaf string markers are inserted in the outer margin of folios to indicate the incipit pages of the sections of and the incipit pages of (on ).

provenance.p: The manuscript was produced by the same scribe who manufactured which belongs to the church of in , Tǝgrāy and was reasonably dated to 1841–1861.

Both codices share, beside the identical handwriting, particular scribal practices. They show similar elements for the visual organisation: an almost identical ornamental band on the incipit page of the first text (more elaborated in than in ; in other reserved spaces for ornamental bands do exist but were not filled) and a very similar way of rubricating the incipit pages of texts and their sections (at the top: two red lines followed by two black and another two red lines; at the bottom: two red lines and two black lines). The name of the patron or scribe or owner, originally written in red ink throughout both manuscripts, was deleted. There is only one instance, found in (see, e.g. ), where the original text layer is still (but barely) readable. This text passage points to the original name of ገብረ፡ ማርያም፡ (in this case, this original name was replaced in with one and the same name, see below).

However, in addition to the attested similar scribal practices, both codices share also physical peculiarities. Both have a quite particular, slender book format (more pronounced in ). Each cover shows a fine and careful blind-tooled decoration. Both have threads inserted into folios for navigation through the multiple-text-manuscripts; has also marks painted in red to indicate the incipit page of a text or of a section. Extremely striking are two labels of two textile companies, one is glued into the inner part of the front board in and the other is sewn onto in (see ). shows the label of “W&I Peel”, the (later) company of the successful textile industrialist Robert Peel (1723–1795), widely known as (the label displays the Peel arms including a shuttle held by a lion, below a bee and the family motto 'Industria'; it is the same as provided in Wikipedia (, accessed on 25 May 2020). Both labels are related most probably to the silk or cotton inlays in both manuscripts and .
We therefore may conclude that and were manufactured around the same time, somewhen between 1841–1861, in the area of , Tǝgrāy in Ethiopia by a professional scribe with connections to foreign traders or at least to imported goods.

Coming back to : The name of the original patron or donor (introduced as ገበርከ፡ ‘your servant’) was erased from the supplication formulas throughout the manuscript. Only the first part of his name ገብረ፡ survived. His name was replaced by that of . The name of written by the main hand is mentioned only once, on .

The manuscript must have come into the possession of the church of Maqdala Madḫāne ʾĀlam at a certain time in its history from where it was looted on 13 April 1868 (see ) and brought to England. It is unknown how and when the manuscript came into the possession of .
